You cannot have a shooting policy other than "shoot to kill." There is no such thing as a "shoot to wound" doctrine in law enforcement. The kind of scenes where the hero shoots from the hip and deliberately shoots the gun out of the bad guy's hand or intentionally "wings" him in the leg so he can be caught and arrested only happen in movies. I have never heard of a police force being taught anything other than "if you must shoot, then shoot to kill." 
 
 I would also be surprised if the "shoot to kill policy" that is being talked about here is new. You simply cannot change a firearms training doctrine overnight. LE officers go through several days if not weeks (depending on where you are) of firearm training, and I would bet that in London when new recruits went through their firearms training course they were taught from the beginning that if you must shoot then shoot to kill. And like every other police agency when the new recruits fired their weapons in training they would have been practicing to do just that. I seriously doubt that the rules and training procedures for officer involved shootings have changed much in three weeks.
 
 What you have in London is a tragic accident that deserves a thorough and fair inquiry. I have investigated officer involved shootings before, and I can tell you it is very rare that the number or placement of shots fired is an issue. The more critical question involves whether the officers legitimately felt they were justified in using their firearms. If the inquiry into the London shooting is to be a proper one, then my bet is it will focus on why the officers felt the need to fire their weapons at all and not on where their shots landed. This is a difficult question to answer, because it requires you to try and place yourself in their shoes, in the heat of the moment, relying on what they knew then and not what you know now, while factoring in what their training and experience would have been telling them when they decided to draw and fire. First and foremost, a thorough inquiry needs the cooperation of the officers involved. It needs them to be honest about what they heard, saw, and felt that led to their decision to shoot. I trust that they will be honest about it, because they should know that their explanation of what happened will be compared to the physical evidence the inquiry uncovers.

I've never see or heard of a shoot to wound policy, and I believe it's so because it's just too hard to do anything other than shoot at the biggest target presented when under pressure. I've never shot at anything that was actively trying to kill me before, so I can't imagine the pressure that factor creates. I've done some training shooting with LE before, however, and I'd like to pretend that I'm a good shot. Yet I will confess that the hits aren't always exactly where I thought they were aimed, particularly if I and/or the target is in motion. The center mass theory was explained to me once as "any bullet which strikes the target is far better than one which flies off into oblivion," and knowing that shooting under pressure is extremely difficult even for those trained to do it you must shoot for the largest target you have.
 
 If anything changed in London since July 7, it would likely be a change in who will now carry firearms regularly and/or a policy change over the rules of engagement for when a firearm may be used to end a perceived threat.
 
 In any event, all LE training I am familiar with treats any shooting incident as an application of deadly force, not wounding force. Most LE shootings involve a belief that the officer needed to apply deadly force in self defense, and the inevitable post-shooting inquiry is designed to test the legitimacy of that belief. I don't know enough of the facts from the London incident, but it appears that the justification here will be defense of others, and the inquiry will likely focus on whether the officers were justified in believing that the unfortunate victim was presenting an imminent threat of deadly force to others which justified the use of their firearms to end that perceived threat. 
 
 No matter how the facts bear out, however, I think the ultimate responsibility lies at the feet of those who chose to create the tension which led to this shooting by waging their secretive and malicious brand of warfare against the heart of an otherwise civil society. Those responsible for the London attacks deserve to reap what they have sown. So long as it's done in a measured way against clearly identified and responsible enemies, then I will have no problem applauding any attempt by Mr. Blair to do his own remake of "The Empire Strikes Back."
